_exec_summary.SummaryText:
INTRODUCTION



TradeMark Nitrogen Corporation (TradeMark) is a producer of nitrogen-based solutions located in Tampa, Florida.  An integral component of the manufacture of these products is anhydrous ammonia.  Inventory exceeds the 10,000-pound threshold for anhydrous ammonia set by the USEPA under the Risk Management Program (RMP) Rule codified at 40 CFR 68.  Pursuant to the requirements of the rule, TradeMark has prepared a RMP Plan.  TradeMark has an outstanding record in environmental, health and safety programs.  The following sections outline our RMP program.



OVERALL RESPONSIBILITY



TradeMark's Environmental, Health and Safety Manager serves as the facility's RMP and PSM Coordinator.  Together with the TradeMark Management Team they share the responsibility for ensuring that the facility operates in a safe and reliable manner.  This responsibility includes overseeing the implementation of the risk management program.  To ensure that the RMP is appropriately developed and implemented, TradeMark's President has assigned the duties of RMP Coordinator to the Environmental, Health and Safety Manager, a staff member who has the necessary background, training and experience to manage the program.  The RMP Coordinator, acting with proper authority has the responsibility for the development, implementation and integration of the USEPA RMP elements.  In addition, the RMP Coordinator works closely with all of the site managers to integrate the elements of the OSHA PSM program as required by Section 68.15 of the RMP rule.

The RMP Coordinator is the Chairman of the facility's RMP Steering Committee.  This committee is comprised of members with responsibilities for developing and managing specific elements of the RMP and PSM programs.  The committee members are assigned by the facility President based on recommendations from the RMP Coordinator.  The following sections identify the specific responsibilities for the various aspects of the RMP and PSM programs.



HAZA

RD ASSESSMENT



The Technical Manager has the responsibility for (1) ensuring the off-site consequence analysis for the regulated process is consistently performed and documented in accordance with Sections 68.20 through 68.39 and (2) selecting the scenarios that will be reported in the facility RMP as required under Section 68.165.  The Environmental, Health and Safety Manager is responsible for ensuring that the accident history for the covered process is appropriately documented and maintained in accordance with sections 68.42 and 68.168 of the RMP rule.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



TradeMark has had no reportable releases of anhydrous ammonia since the facility opened on this site in 1983.



PREVENTION PROGRAM



The RMP and PSM Coordinator has the responsibility of ensuring that the facility has an integrated, effective and compliant prevention program that meets Sections 68.65 through 68.87 of the RMP rule and OSHA PSM requirements.  The Coordinator holds many of specific responsibilities but some of the specific program elements are assigned to other members of the RMP/PSM Steering Committee.



PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION



The responsibility for process safety information, Section 68.65 of the RMP rule is divided between the Environmental, Health and Safety Manager (process chemical and equipment information) and the Technical Manager (process technology information).  The RMP Coordinator has the responsibility of ensuring that all of the information is readily accessible for use.



PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS



In accordance with RMP Section 68.57, the PSM Coordinator has the responsibility for scheduling, conducting and documenting that the PHAs were completed by trained personnel for the covered process.  The RMP and PSM Coordinators designate appropriately trained personnel from within the facility to participate in the PHAs.  The Coordinators may elect to use outside contractors to lead the PHAs.  Other members of the RMP Steering Committee are ch

arged with the staffing of the PHA meeting and ensuring that PHA recommendations are resolved in a timely manner.



OPERATING PROCEDURES



In accordance with RMP Section 68.69, the Production Manager must ensure that complete and accurate operating procedures are in place for the regulated process.  The Production Manager works with the Technical Manager and the Environmental, Health and Safety Manager to develop and maintain the facility's safe work practices.



TRAINING



In accordance with RMP Section 68.71, the Environmental, Health and Safety Manager has the responsibility for (1) ensuring that operations employees receive and understand training applicable to their specific jobs and associated processes and (2) documenting said training. The Environmental, Health and Safety Manager and the Technical Manager share the responsibility for (1) ensuring that all employees receive and understand training in safe work practices applicable to their jobs and (2) documenting said training.



MECHANICAL INTEGRITY



In accordance with RMP Section 68.73 the Technical Manager has the responsibility for overall mechanical integrity program, with specific emphasis on written procedures, maintenance training, the equipment and instrumentation inspection/testing program and documentation, and equipment deficiency resolution.  TradeMark employs contractors and/or consultants to assist in the implementation and maintenance of the mechanical integrity program.  The Technical Manager works with appropriate maintenance personnel to define and maintain appropriate quality assurance procedures for equipment acquisitions/installations/repairs.



MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE



In accordance with RMP Section 68.75, the RMP and PSM Coordinator has the overall responsibility for the management of change (MOC) program; however, the Technical Manager has responsibility for ensuring that the overall MOC program is effectively implemented.



PRE-STARTUP SAFETY REVIEW



In accordance with RMP

Section 68.77, the RMP and PSM Coordinator has the responsibility for the overall pre-startup safety review program, which is closely related to the MOC program. However, the Production Manager and the Environmental, Health and Safety Manager have the combined responsibility for ensuring that this program is effectively implemented before affected operations begin.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS



In accordance with RMP Section 68.79, the RMP and PSM Coordinator has the responsibility for ensuring that compliance audits regularly occur (and are documented) to verify that the prevention program is working and meets EPA/OSHA requirements.  Each member of the RMP/PSM Steering Committee has responsibility for resolving any identified deficiency in his area.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION



In accordance with RMP Section 68.81, the Environmental, Health and Safety Manager has the responsibility for designing and managing the incident investigation program, including tracking resolution of investigation findings and recommendations.   The Technical Manager has the responsibility of ensuring that only trained personnel lead investigations.  The Environmental, Health and Safety and Production Managers share the responsibility for ensuring that all incidents are reported and investigated in a timely manner, and that investigation findings are resolved, documented and communicated to affected personnel.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION



In accordance with RMP Section 68.83, the RMP and PSM Coordinator, working with employee representatives on the RMP/PSM Steering Committee, share the responsibility of involving employees in the planning and implementation of the facility's prevention program elements.



HOT WORK PERMITS



In accordance with RMP Section 68.85, the Environmental, Health and Safety Manager has responsibility for developing and maintaining the facility's hot work permit program.



CONTRACTORS



In accordance with RMP Section 68.87, the Technical Manager has overall responsibi

lity for the contractor program; however, the Environmental, Health and Safety Manager is responsible for ensuring that the requirements of the program are implemented in his area of responsibility.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



In accordance with RMP Sections 68.90 and 68.95, the Environmental, Health and Safety Manager is responsible for (1) designing, implementing and maintaining the facility's emergency response plan, (2) ensuring that all associated training is conducted and documented as necessary, (3) coordinating the site emergency response plan with the community response plan and (4) responding to local emergency planners/responders when questions arise.  TradeMark employees would not respond in the event of an emergency release.  Personnel are trained to immediately notify the appropriate facility managers.  Although TradeMark employees would not actively participate in emergency response activities, they would be available to assist appropriately trained personnel in other critical aspects of the emergency response.  In such a situation, TradeMark employees may be called upon to provide details on the process, equipment locations, and/or other facility-specific details that may be integral to emergency response activities.



RMP PLAN PREPARATION AND SUBMISSION



The Environmental, Health and Safety Manager is responsible for preparing and submitting the PMP Plan for the facility (after review and approval by the President) as required by RMP Sections 68.150 through 68.185.



RMP PLAN COMMUNICATION



The President and the Environmental, Health and Safety Manager have the responsibility of providing RMP Plan information (other than the required USEPA submission) to employees and the public as required by RMP Section 68.210.  TradeMark has been an active participant in community outreach efforts to communicate the details and implications of its RMP to the members of the potentially affected public.
